awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ProteoCell: The Fat-Free Cell
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to build functional, lipid-free, 'living' cells by using proteins to create multi-compartment 'ProteoCells' that can self-generate, house reactions to produce products, interact with other ProteoCells, and in total, define a new type of cell-like structure with fundamentally novel properties. Cells are the most basic unit defining living systems, yet despite years of study, it remains unclear why nature chose to use lipids as its hallmark compartment-formers, and how compartmentalization enables a complex 'soup' of biological molecules to function as an autonomous and self-sustainable unit. This project addresses these questions by using engineering principles to design new protein synthesis reactions, new compartment-forming proteins, and new protein catalysts, and by studying how these 'designer' protein molecules interact with one another to create collective cell-like units. This work will address fundamental Rules of Life questions surrounding the roles of lipids and proteins as essential cellular 'building blocks,' and the importance of compartmentalization in cellular function. Synthetic ProteoCells may ultimately provide an innovative tool to solve societal problems related to human health, sustainability, and the environment. Development of the ProteoCell platform also provides unique educational opportunities and opportunities to engage in a two-way dialog with the public regarding the meaning of a synthetic cell, and the possibilities, benefits, and concerns related to creating new forms of cellular life.

Scientifically, this project will define how to 'bottom-up' construct lipid-free ProteoCells, including a self-assembling physical boundary, a genetically programmable cytoplasm, and encapsulated multicomponent reactions. ProteoCells will provide insights into the relationship between the dynamic synthesis of polypeptide/protein building blocks, their self-assembly, and the design rules to create functional ProteoCells that can ultimately self-generate and self-support. The project approach consists of modular and iterative engineering, production, and integration of membrane-forming polypeptides/proteins; protein machinery for CO2 transformation; and machinery to support gene expression. The four aims of the project will create composable ProteoCells and define the range of possible properties; construct rudimentary organelles and define the properties necessary for producing organic molecules from CO2; build multi-cellular ProteoCell 'communities' with defined organization; and probe the US public's perceptions of risks/benefits of constructing a synthetic cell.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are the common denominator of all living systems as they carry out the essential functions of the living. Therefore, the condition of their synthesis is critical when it comes to the survival of a living organism. On the one hand, every living cell uses the information stored in its DNA to achieve protein synthesis through the transcription of a messenger RNA, which is then translated into a protein by a ribosome. On the other hand, encapsulating the transcription-translation molecular components into cell-sized compartments is an essential trait of living cells.

In this project, we developed a method to achieve cell-free protein synthesis while using materials of the smallest degree of biological complexity. In this regard, we abstained from using fatty amphiphilic molecules such as phospholipids, that form the natural membranes of cells. Instead, we used the process of liquid-liquid phase separation. Large molecules, such as polymers, when present in sufficient amounts in water, give rise to the spontaneous formation of distinct domains with different compositions that are known as phases. We used this property of polymers to create compartments that specifically host cell-free protein synthesis without a physical membrane. We created an experimental platform that can achieve cell-free protein synthesis in vitro, i.e., without the constraints of working in living cells, using a medium taken in part from E. coli bacteria cytoplasm, that reproduces the two-step process of protein synthesis from DNA, and named TXTL for cell-free transcription-translation. The versatility and robustness of the TXTL system allow it to be adapted to a great variety of physical and chemical conditions and protein synthesis applications.

We found that adding poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG), poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and Dextran to a TXTL reaction spontaneously forms three phases: two discrete phases made of distinct droplets of two different compositions, and a continuous phase that surrounds the droplets. Among the two discrete phases, one is made of droplets rich in PEG and PVA, the other is rich in Dextran. We found that while the droplets rich in PEG and PVA are devoid of DNA and produce no protein, the droplets rich in Dextran sequester most of the DNA present in the TXTL reaction and thus host the reaction of protein synthesis. We could synthesize a broad range of proteins and show that they localize in different parts of the Dextran-rich droplets: globular proteins, very soluble in water and without particular affinity with membranes, are uniformly distributed inside the Dextran-rich droplets; proteins that interact with or insert themselves into membranes show a significant localization at the interface of the Dextran-rich droplets, in spite of the absence of any physical membrane; and proteins responsible for the formation of bacterial micro-compartments localize exclusively at the interface of Dextran-rich droplets.

The droplets in a phase-separated TXTL (PSTXTL) reaction eventually grow bigger through coalescence. In order to mitigate that effect and extend the life expectancy of the Dextran-rich droplets, we added a gelation agent, agarose to our PEG-PVA-Dextran-TXTL system and realized that it helped form Dextran-rich droplets in smaller sizes and larger number.

A sufficiently large concentration of polymers is necessary for phase-separation of the PSTXTL system to happen, which can be detrimental to reaching high yields of protein synthesis. To help form distinct droplets with polymers, one could use surfactants. Since in the scope of this project we cannot resort to using fatty acids and phospholipids, we had to come up with a different source of surfactants. Before the formation of the first fatty amphiphilic molecules polymer chains already existed in the form of peptides. Since amino acids can be either hydrophilic or hydrophobic, it appears sensible that amphiphilic peptides may have existed before fatty amphiphilic molecules. In a more general view, we succeeded in lowering the amount of polymer necessary for phase separation by adding non-fatty amphiphilic molecules in the form the amphiphilic diblock copolymers, large molecules that are the association of two different polymeric chains, one being a repeat of hydrophilic monomers, the other, of hydrophobic monomers. Such molecules are chemically not considered as fat or lipids.

Not only did we manage to create a family of compartments based on simple polymers that can specifically host protein synthesis, but we also showed through our collaboration with other teams that this platform can be combined with other techniques to circumvent its limitations.
